entities.name: EwA Buggy
entities.goal: Help EwA build arthropod interaction networks.
entities.task: Document arthropod activity, abundance, phenology, and hosts.
entities.description: Help EwA document arthropod interaction networks so that we can understand better arthropod activity and their association dynamic with their floral hosts. ⓘ More about EwA's Biodiversity and Climate Participatory Science program at www.earthwiseaware.org/citizen-science.
entities.how_to_join:
Steps you can take to get involved in the project

Participants in EwA Arthropod Monitoring are asked to take a training that helps them build skills to identify local flora and their arthropod visitors and follow a scientific protocol to collect information and submit it to the project. Many participants do their training at an in-person session > Join an EwA field orientation session. You can also use the provided resource if no training is offered near you.

If you are located in the Greater Boston Area, you may also be interested in setting up a study site near you. If so, feel free to contact us so that we can best help you.
entities.materials: Phone camera, or camera. Magnifying lens if camera zoom is not good enough.
entities.location_landuse: Parks, garden, forest, meadow, and the like
entities.participation_schedule: Anytime, but preferably on a regular basis
entities.special_skills: Learn how to identify orders of arthropod and host plant species. Learn how to observe and document length, activity, behavior.
entities.data_results: Data is discoverable, aggregated with other EwA data, and intended to be pushed to global interaction platforms.

data_consent.label: Through a generic terms of use agreement

data_access.label: Bulk download of all data at once (e.g. by FTP download)

entities.data_license: Licensed under Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.

entities.name: EwA Pheno Lite
entities.goal: Document the phenology of local flora species so that we can better understand the timing of seasonal events in relat...
entities.task: Observe familiar flora species throughout the seasons, and record their developmental phases at regular time intervals.
entities.description: In nature, timing is everything. Help Earthwise Aware (EwA) document the phenology of common flora species so that we can better understand the timing of seasonal events in relation to bird and insect activities. ⓘ More about EwA's Biodiversity and Climate Participatory Science program at www.earthwiseaware.org/citizen-science

entities.name: iSeaTree
entities.goal: Help resource managers study and record the benefits of urban trees!
entities.task: Collect and track the air pollution, carbon, and water benefits of urban trees!
entities.description: 'iSeaTree' is an application for identifying and tracking urban trees. It works with the USFS's 'iTree' API to calculate the CO2, H2O, and pollution benefits of trees anywhere within the United States and Canada. It also has built-in tree surveying tools (like an AI to help identify the tree species) which help beginners in entering complete and accurate data about trees in their region. 'iSeaTree' turns app-users into citizen scientists and helps communities protect and preserve their urban canopies.
entities.practices_how: 'iSeaTree' is a data gathering platform that utilizes the US Forest Service's 'iTree' API to calculate the CO2, H2O, and pollution benefits of trees anywhere within the United States and Canada. By entering all the required data fields a user can submit the data to the USFS's 'iTree' API and have it return the 'tree benefit' results that 'iTree' calculates. All of this information is then saved to a database where resource managers and scientists can access the data to construct land use models and plans.
entities.how_to_join:
Head to treemama.org to learn more about the project.

Check out the introductory video on youtube:

https://youtu.be/FmJS34PjfhQ

Then, download the app and start identifying trees!
entities.consent_statement: iSeaTree requests that all users who login and use the app understand that tree surveys should only happen on public property (like in the street ROW or in parks) or on private property where landowners have granted permission. Users are also required to consent that any harm done to a tree is not sanctioned nor the responsibility of the app developers.
entities.materials:
1) an android or ios mobile phone
2) measuring tape OR DBH tape (optional)
entities.data_results: All data is saved in our cloud database and is available via a direct request made on our website.

entities.value: Peace Boat US - Youth for the SDGs program for the UN Ocean Decade
entities.name: Peace Boat US - Youth for the SDGs program for the UN Ocean Decade
entities.goal: Youth traveling for ocean and climate action
entities.task: Observe marine life, ocean currents and learn from communities
entities.description:
Youth for the SDGs Scholarship
- A program for the United Nations Decade of Ocean Science for Sustainable Development -

Peace Boat US is excited to announce the launch of a new series of programs as part of the United Nations Decade of Ocean Science for Sustainable Development to be held onboard Peace Boat. Highlighting the theme of this year’s UN World Oceans Day: “Planet Ocean: Tides are Changing, we seek to raise awareness about Life Below Water and encourage positive action for our blue planet


​
Dates and Programs for the United Nations Ocean Decade 2023:

 Arctic Voyage:
Tilbury (London) UK - Sailing through the Fjords of Norway - Iceland
May 24 - June 14, 2023

Latin American Voyage:
Panama - Sailing through the Panama Canal - Guatemala - Mexico
June 20 - July 5, 2023
entities.practices_how: Youth will participate in citizen science programs in every port of call we visit during the Peace Boat Global Voyage, testing water samples and recording data for the United Nations Decade of Ocean Science for Sustainable Development. Observations, education onboard, lectures, workshops and hands-on experiences in the ports will be included in the program.
entities.how_to_join: Please sign up via the link on our website to join a Global Voyage and apply for the program today! We will have programs every year onboard the Peace Boat.
entities.materials: This will include the travel onboard the Peace Boat for the project
entities.location_landuse: Onboard the Peace Boat and in the ports of call
entities.location_description: Arctic (From London through the Fjords of Norway to Iceland)  and Latin America  (From Panama, through the Panama Canal to Guatemala and Mexico)
entities.data_results: WE will upload the data to the UN Ocean Decade Ocean Data System and provide the data to EarthEcho International for the Water Challenge website.

data_consent.label: Through a generic terms of use agreement

entities.name: BMER Flora Research
entities.goal: To capture a biological picture of Burton Mesa Ecological Reserve near distinct water features following a historic atmospheric river event in the region.
entities.task: Use iNaturalist to capture interesting plants in Lompoc, Ca.
entities.description: Two environmental science enthusiasts collecting data on select sites in an ecological reserve to get a better picture of the flora communities and how climate change is impacting them.

entities.name: The Bio-Expertise Engine
entities.goal: The BEE raises the value of nature by rewarding people for their expertise.
entities.task: Help identify QuestaGame sightings via a collective human intelligence system.
entities.description:
The Bio-Expertise Engine (BEE) seeks to raise the value of nature conservation by rewarding people for their nature expertise.

BEE helps connect QuestaGame players' sightings with people who know nature. It's a collective human intelligence system that helps get the best identification back to the player as quickly as possible. As an expert, when you help identify sightings through BEE, the benefits are huge!

You are not only helping budding naturalists grow their knowledge and ensuring high-quality data for biodiversity researchers, but you are also raising money for your chosen environmental cause (through the Pays to Know Nature Fund)!
entities.how_to_join:
Keen to get involved but not sure how to use BEE? 

It is designed to be pretty intuitive, so feel free to jump in and have a go. But if you need a hand, here are some steps to follow:

1. Go to Bio-Expertise Engine (http://BioExpertise.org)
2. Click 'sign-up' on the left-hand navigation (or if you already have a QuestaGame account, you can log in with that)
3. Select 'Settings' from the left-hand navigation. This will help you filter sightings so that you only see those relevant to your area of interest.
 - Select your 'Categories of Expertise' and hit 'save'.
 - Click 'Add Region'. Drag and squeeze the grey box to cover your chosen area and hit 'save'.
4. Before you start identifying sightings, be sure also to register for the Pays To Know Nature Fund so that you can earn money for your chosen cause with every correct identification you submit.
5. Now you are ready to identify sightings through either BEE's:
 - 'Home' view, which serves up one sighting at a time; or
 - 'Browse sightings' view, which offers a grid view of multiple sightings.
6. To identify a sighting:
 - First, assess the information provided with the sighting to decide if you are confident in providing an identification. If not, scroll to the bottom and hit 'Skip'. 
 You can click the arrows next to the image to see multiple photos if provided. And you can click the image for a larger version.
 There may be valuable information in the player's field notes.
 - If you are confident that you can provide identification, enter the scientific name in the required field. This will search the GBIF database for matching taxa. Simply select the correct taxon. If the search does not give the desired result, consider if GBIF may use a synonym for that species. You can also search by common name.
The confidence rating will be set to 'I am very confident', but you can lower this confidence rating if required.
The taxon level will be set automatically based on your selection.
 - Add any comments you may have, but these aren't mandatory. 
 - Hit submit, and identify the next sighting.
7. Remember that you can also view your 'Past work' via the left-hand navigator, and this can be a useful reference if you come across a sighting that looks a bit familiar!

location_type.label: Online only (The entire activity takes place at a computer or on a smart phone)

activities.label: At a science center, zoo or aquarium

entities.data_results: We strongly promote open data exchange while at the same time protecting individual rights to the data. For more information, see https://questagame.com/terms-conditions or contact info@questagame.com.

entities.name: Julia: A Science Journey
entities.goal: To understand how video games can promote critical thinking
entities.task: You just need to play the game!
entities.description:
Julia: a Science Journey is a video game about viruses, society, and life choices. The story begins in 2020 as our main character lives a humdrum teenage life while she deals with high school, her family and her friends. Will you help Julia navigate through the complexities of adult life while the COVID-19 pandemic changes her world forever?

Julia: ASJ is part of the DiHealthEd project which is an innovative scientific initiative on Digital Education supported by the Catalan Research Agency and  led by the DIDPATRI research group at the Universitat de Barcelona. The mission of DiHealthEd is to evaluate the potential of video game-based learning to promote critical and scientific thinking in the context of the current global emergencies such as the COVID-19 pandemic and climate change.
entities.practices_how: The project promotes scientific literacy and critical thinking as the participants will play a game which integrates mechanics and content linked to a diversity of knowledge fields such as biology, history, and philosophy. It also fosters curiosity about science and interest on the persons that ultimately become scientists.
entities.how_to_join: Everybody willing to contribute can help us achieve this research objective. How? Simple: just play Julia: A Science Journey! While you play, anonymous information will be recorded about your game choices and the ways you face and master the challenges posed by game mechanics.

location_type.label: Online only (The entire activity takes place at a computer or on a smart phone)

entities.special_skills: None. We want to collect data from a diversity of players so you are not required to have previous experience with video games.
entities.data_results: It will be openly available as a dataset under an Open Data license at the university data repository.

entities.name: EwA Invasive Flora Patrol
entities.goal: Help ecological assessment and management of sensitive areas.
entities.description: Document occurrence (location) and density data of invasive flora in urban parks, city gardens, and private backyards...
entities.how_to_join:
Participants in EwA Invasive Flora Monitoring are asked to take a training that helps them build skills to identify invasive flora and follow a scientific protocol to collect information and submit it to the project. Many participants do their training at an in-person session > Join an EwA field orientation. You can also use the provided resource if no training is offered near you.

If you are located in the Greater Boston Area, you may also be interested in setting up a study site near you. If so, contact usopen_in_new, and tell us where and why you want to start a systematic survey at your location.

Who can join?

You do not have to be a plant expert to be an observer! The only requirements are:

You are located in the Greater Boston Area
* An interest in native plant communities and how to preserve them;
* A willingness to become a trained volunteer and join an EwA field orientation if one is in your area; and
* A commitment to follow the EwA protocol to document invasive species, possibly several times over the course of a year.
entities.participation_confirmation_message:
Please register as a member on one of our project platforms (whichever you prefer) 
* Anecdata platform: https://www.anecdata.org/projects/view/1155
* CitSci platform: https://www.citsci.org/projects/ewa-invasive-flora-monitoring
entities.materials: Smart device / upload the app and join project on the app.
entities.participation_schedule: Opportunistic is fine. Once a month preferred.
entities.special_skills: Know your invasive species, and have rudimentary phenology knowledge
entities.data_results: Open. Analyzed. Aggregated with other ecological factors. Added to GIS Map when applicable.

entities.name: Cloudspotting On Mars

references.label: Be a Citizen Scientist With the “Cloudspotting on Mars” Project

entities.task: Find clouds on Mars to help scientists study the Martian atmosphere.
entities.description:
Clouds are a familiar feature in the atmospheres of planets. Because they can both warm and cool the atmosphere, they are important for understanding the weather and climate of planets. On Mars, icy clouds can form high in the atmosphere (above 50 km, about 30 miles up), the "mesosphere," called "mesospheric clouds". These clouds are interesting for several reasons. Although Mars is a dry planet, there is water vapor in the atmosphere that can form water-ice clouds. However, because the atmosphere of Mars is made up almost entirely (95%) of carbon-dioxide and it is cold, carbon-dioxide ice (think dry ice!) clouds can also form.

Some important questions about these clouds:
* What causes the atmosphere to get cold enough for carbon-dioxide to freeze out?
* How do clouds change from day to night, or during different seasons, or in some years more than others?
* What are the clouds made of?
Our goal with this project is to first find and map these clouds to create a database that will help answer such questions.

To do this, we'll be searching through data acquired by the Mars Climate Sounder (MCS) on the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter (MRO). MCS is an instrument that peers at the horizon of the planet in the infrared and visible to measure temperature, water-ice, and dust content of the atmosphere on Mars. From nearly the first day that MCS sent data back to Earth, strange features were observed at high altitudes. These features have an arch-like or loop shape to them and have since been recognized to be clouds.
entities.how_to_join: Head to the zooniverse project site, read through the tutorial, and get started: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/marek-slipski/cloudspotting-on-mars

location_type.label: Online only (The entire activity takes place at a computer or on a smart phone)

entities.data_results: We plan to aggregate and anonymize the data and make it publicly available on an open archive.

entities.value: Time to Restore: Connecting People, Plants, and Pollinators
entities.name: Time to Restore: Connecting People, Plants, and Pollinators
entities.goal: Help pollinators by tracking flowering and seed timing of plants
entities.task: Track flowering and seed timing of one or more nectar plants where you live
entities.description: When planting to support pollinators, we need to know which species to plant to provide nectar during critical periods, and how these plant species will respond to changes in climate including more variable weather conditions. A new effort across the South Central US, called Time to Restore: Connecting People, Plants, and Pollinators, seeks to generate better information about flowering and seed timing for critical nectar plants, and the links between this activity and climate.
entities.practices_how: Participants can make predictions about when plants will flower and go to seed, and how one year might compare to the next.
entities.how_to_join:
1. Visit the Time to Restore landing page to see the priority species we are interested in for this project: https://www.usanpn.org/TimetoRestore

2. Join Nature's Notebook and set up a site and add one or more nectar plants: https://www.usanpn.org/nn/become-observer

3. Make observations once per week, if possible, recording flowering and seed questions. 

4. Sign up for Nectar Connectors emails to see results from data collection on these Time to Restore priority species and other nectar species across the country: https://lp.constantcontactpages.com/su/q5UDhyi/NectarConnectors
entities.location_landuse: Any location where you can find these nectar plant species
entities.location_description: States of New Mexico, Oklahoma, Texas, and Louisiana
entities.participation_schedule: Once per week is preferred, but any contributions are welcome
entities.special_skills: Participants need to be able to locate and identify one or more of the priority nectar plant species.
entities.data_results: The data are made publicly available via USA National Phenology Network tools.

data_consent.label: Through a generic terms of use agreement

data_access.label: Bulk download of all data at once (e.g. by FTP download)
